subject: Re: Mock objects...
msgSnippet: Greetings, ... _JUnit ... Heh...  Plug, plug, plug.  No argument, I ll probably read it, I m enough of a JUnit fan for that.  I ve read several other books and
messageBody:
Greetings,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> cypherfox wrote:
>
> > How the heck do people mock things like database
> > access classes, mail servers, arbitrary web requests,
> > etc., without writing a huge amount of logic?
>
> Surprisingly easily. You might just need some good examples. See
_JUnit
> Recipes_, part 2, for details.

Heh... Plug, plug, plug. No argument, I'll probably read it, I'm
enough of a JUnit fan for that. I've read several other books and
none seems to clearly define how a mock object is supposed to
behave, or how complex you're supposed to make them.

> > What am I missing?
>
> It's tough to say. Without looking at a specific example, I can't
say
> much more. Can you get concrete about a mock you wrote that
exploded out
> of control? Can we see code?

Sure, the most recent example of this to me, was this class:
http://www.vixen.com/code/JournalHash.java
implementing
http://www.vixen.com/code/JournalDataStore.java

(All the JavaDoc is in the interface, which is why I put that
there also, mildly sanitized so my company name isn't
out there.)

One of the things that isn't even in there, is the concept of
'get most recent 'n' entries', because that would require me
to walk backwards through the TreeMap, or add a *third*
representation of the same data, as a linked list or something.

I found it frustrating to have to do this much work for what
was really just a testing class. It DID let me put off doing
the JDBC code until later, however. Thankfully it was a
'generic' enough interface that the code didn't change
noticably when doing the actual DB storage code.

-- Morgan Schweers
